content: I have made some modifications to the statement to improve grammar and clarity, and I have voted to approve this puzzle.

There may exists issues in some cases, like "En passant ".  First, the Move "h5g6" seems illegal, because h5 is a  "P" and g6 is empty, no enemy there. And even this move is ok, the answer is also not fit the chessboard. 

The detailed output listed below--

src:2kr3r/1pp1qppp/2np1n2/p3p2P/1bB1P1b1/2NP1N2/PPPBQPP1/2KR3R
..kr...r
.pp.qppp
..np.n..
p...p..P
.bB.P.b.
..NP.N..
PPPBQPP.
..KR...R

Move: g7g5, understand as [6 1]->[6 3] ()
..kr...r
.pp.qp.p
..np.n..
p...p.pP
.bB.P.b.
..NP.N..
PPPBQPP.
..KR...R

Move: h5g6, understand as [7 3]->[6 2] ()
..kr...r
.pp.qp.p
..np.nP.
p...p.p.
.bB.P.b.
..NP.N..
PPPBQPP.
..KR...R
2kr3r/1pp1qp1p/2np1nP1/p3p1p1/1bB1P1b1/2NP1N2/PPPBQPP1/2KR3R

Failure
Found:  2kr3r/1pp1qp1p/2np1nP1/p3p1
Expected:  2kr3r/1pp1qp1p/2np1nP1/p3p3
I like it. Will definitely approve once I have actually solved it :)

I prefer not to explain all the chess moves in order to keep the statement brief and easy to read.

If anyone don't know anything about chess rules, please search on internet the following topics:
castling
en passant
pawn promotion

Basic moves are not neccesary to know for solving this puzzle.

Thanks for your vote!

I'm ok with not explaining the basic moves if they're not needed, but I'd rather have a local description of the weirder rules (the three you named: castling, passant, promotion), because as it is, they're still ambiguous.

Ambiguous about castling: how are we supposed to know whether the initial board position you give already castled?

En passant: mostly the same.

Promotion: notation issue, does the N mean the pawn promotes to a white knight, or do we assume queen?

Or don't use them. Problems are much better when they're self-contained.
I think the move "g7g5" should be "g7g6"

OK,  thanks.
How about add some wiki links or some keywords about the 3 special move rules?
Or add an example about "En passant" just like the other 2.

"Example: "e7e8Q" you must remove the pawn on e7 square and place a white queen on e8 square.
Example: "e1g1" you must remove the king on e1 square and place on g1 square, (but king can't move more than 1 square except when he is castling), so you must move the rook on h1 square to f1 square in order to complete the castling move.
"
I have added an "en passant" move example. Thanks for the comments.

I have added a couple of examples with weird moves.

You don't need to know if the board position is already castled because all the moves you have to make are legal. You don't need to worry about if the pieces can make the move or not.

If  you have to make a castling move on a specific position, you can be sure the move can be made perfectly.

Thank you for the comment.
